Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Linguistic Analysis of Grammatical Constructions in Discourse about Civic and Economic Issues

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will address the complex ways in which social, civic, economic, and linguistic factors interact to provoke or prevent the accelerated process of language shift of indigenous languages. Simultaneously, it will document a specialized genre. Growing evidence shows that more specialized genres and knowledge in languages are vulnerable to attrition. Through an analysis of particular linguistic elements, the project will provide greater detail about an endangered language that displays a highly complex morphological system. Because the topic is limited to a particular kind of specialized speech (the matters of state), the analysis will also expand knowledge about the role of sociolinguistic and other factors in the linguistic shift, including linguistic ideologies about who should speak a language, how and where it should be spoken. The focus will be on Nahuatl (ISO 639-3 NHE), a Uto-Aztecan language possessing a complex morphology of prefixes and suffixes that interacts with the discursive content of speech. This complex morphology (quite different than English morphology, for example) creates a testing bed for how specialized genres interact with specific aspects of a language, here extensive suffixing and prefixing processes, as well as how different speakers use the same grammatical elements in different ways. Project activities include the development of pedagogical materials, a workshop for elementary school teachers in the village, and the training of two native speakers in linguistic documentation methodologies. Broader impacts include the training of a doctoral student, a public repository of audio and video recordings and transcriptions archived at the University of Texas, Austin's AILLA repository, and the strengthening of collaborations between Mexican and American scholars.

The project will expand knowledge about the linguistic and extra-linguistic factors that influence the maintenance or the shift of one language to another. The project will collect video and audio recordings of the oratory taking place in assemblies made up by women-only, men-only, and mixed groups from Nahua Mexican society to identify rhetorical strategies such as persuasion. This language is spoken in various parts of Mexico; this project will specifically document the variety located on the east-central side of the country. Usage will be analyzed for speaker variation as pertains to particular grammatical elements, as well as more "poetic" kinds of constructions such as metaphor, alliteration, parallelism, anaphora, and metonymy. Through the analyses of grammatical constructions in these civic- and economic-oriented genres, the CoPI will investigate how grammatical constructions and linguistic strategies used in governmental contexts are used by language users to accomplish social goals during the course of speeches on policy and civic topics. An analysis of the markers for linguistic categories like direction or future, frequently found in this specialized genre, will lead to a better understanding of their grammatical properties as well as how speakers of Nahuatl use these structures for different purposes. The researcher will use linguistic ethnography as the central methodology, supplemented by in-depth interviews. Ethnography is a methodology that includes linguistic investigation, participant observation, and recording of spontaneous speaking interactions. The results will provide insights not only for linguistics but also for sociolinguistics, linguistic anthropology, and anthropology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Why is it that indigenous languages are in risk of disappearance? Is there any relationship between language shift, race, and racism? This project focused on language use as a means of linguistic, cultural, and communal resistance against political economic forces of assimilation and racial domination. This research specifically analyzed how the use of Nahuatl (ISO 639-3 NHE), an endangered indigenous language, and Spanish within a Nahua community in Hidalgo, Mexico signifies ideological and power relationships. In Mexico, indigenous languages and their speakers are perceived through a highly racialized lens that is often masked under the guise of Mexico´s ideology of mestizaje. In this context, the project paid particular attention to the dynamics of interaction and communicative practices within assemblies´a key form of local governance. The research showed that the collective force displayed in such spaces might be the engine to transgress, oppose, and challenge the highly racialized language ideology of the state that advocates Spanish as the language of modernization. This colonial and national language ideology contributes to the process of a language shift of the indigenous language.

 

Over several months of fieldwork, the researcher documented Nahuatl political speeches in audio and video that took place in assemblies, paying central attention to ways of communication in the Nahuatl decision-making process and political negotiations in sentilistle (mixed group assemblies), siwasentilistle (women-only assemblies), and tlakasentilistle (men-only assemblies). The video and audio recordings covered various topics such as the elections of the incoming members of the local government -both men and women -, the one-year changing cycle of the members of the local government, negotiations of the introduction of new services to the community, negotiations and attempts to solve agrarian issues with neighboring villages, internal trials for individuals who commit any crimes, and organization of religious festivities and patron saints´ celebrations. Additionally, the researcher also conducted participant observation in various political activities such as komontekitl (communal work) as well as meetings carried out by members of the local government with different committees that are in charge of solving several needs of the community. Finally, the researcher carried out semi-structural and in-depth interviews with current and former members of local governmental system, young citizens, adults, and elders, both men and women.

 

As the approach of this research was ethnographical and linguistic, the former provided the information to describe the political organization of this Nahua society, including the structure of the local government and the local linguistic ideologies that permeate the use of language in political arenas whereas the analysis of the recorded speeches gave the possibility to identify linguistic, pragmatic and discursive elements in the Nahuatl language. Thus, this project examined the variety of linguistic strategies, including morpho-syntactic, rhetorical, prosodic, and pragmatic that speakers mobilize in their assemblies. The analysis described the repertoire of these resources used by this historically racialized group of indigenous speakers and how they are distributed along the lines of gender, age, and class statuses as well as ethnic and racial identities. By describing these linguistic dynamics, the research identified the way in which raciolinguistic ideologies are expressed and challenged in everyday practices of local life.

 

As part of a community-based approach, this linguistic documentation project included the training of two native speakers in documentation methods, recording natural speech events and using specialized software to systematize and analyze. The objective of this training was to empower indigenous youth to continue working with the documentation of their language in the future and ultimately help change negative attitudes towards Nahuatl, raising the local social status of the language. Because this Nahuatl is in danger of extinction, this research gathered a rich corpus of audio and video recordings and transcriptions which will be archived at the Archive of Indigenous Language of Latin America, at the University of Austin, Texas.

 

One of the main outcomes of this research was to identify different linguistic styles, each of which is linked to social evaluations of individuals and their practices (i.e., linguistic ideologies). At the same time, the research explored how groups inside the community, mainly professional and wealthy individuals who have embodied the national project of modernization impose their ideas as to which language should be used and how Nahuatl should be spoken. By exploring how these actors´ linguistic ideologies and practices contribute to hindering the wider use of the Nahuatl language, this study showed that language ideologies and practices are key sites for the organization and reproduction of race and racism. Finally, this analysis contributes to determining why Nahua people prefer to use or not use their native language in public spheres as it gives a frame of the symbolic negotiations between the colonial language, Spanish and the native language, Nahuatl.
